title: Bassoon
description: Fagot met koperen randen en vier messing kleppen. Het bovenste gedeelte is gedecoreerd met een messing kroon. Gemarkeerd op alle delen: I. SCHERER [in een rol]  / [staande leeuw van Hesse].

acquisition.creditLine: Purchased with the support of the State of the Netherlands and the Vereeniging van Noord-Nederlandsche Muziekgeschiedenis

documentation: David Rachor, 'A Bassoon by Hirschstein: The Instrument and Its Possible Use in the Military', The Galpin Society Journal 64 (Mar., 2011), p. 117-124: 119
Phillip T. Young, 'The Scherers of Butzbach', The Galpin Society Journal 39 (Sep., 1986), p. 112-124

L.G. Langwill, 'Musikinstrumenten-Sammlung des Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam ausgestellt im Gemeente Museum, Den Haag 9. Oktober - 24. November 1952', Glareana: Nachrichten der Gesellschaft der Freunde alter Musikinstrumente 2, nr. 2 (1953), p. 1-3: 2
'Aanwinsten', Bulletin van de Nederlandse Oudheidkundige Bond 1, nr. 2 (1899/1900), p. 48-49: 48
subTitle: l 1250mm
scLabelLine: Georg Heinrich Scherer (c. 1711–1778), maple, brass, Butzbach, c. 1750

label.title: Bassoon
label.makerLine: Georg Heinrich Scherer (c. 1711–1778), maple, brass, Butzbach, c. 1750
label.description: The bassoon – from the French bas son – is the low voice of the double reed instruments, while the oboe – hautbois – is the high one. The modern bassoon, consisting of different assembled parts, stems from the mid-17th century. Today’s bassoon serves as the tenor and bass for the orchestra’s woodwinds.
